I personally chose "End of biologically possible mental existence" (which corresponds to the permanent loss of cerebral cortex function) since I view that, once we no longer mentally exist, then the only thing that exists after us is our artificially sustained continued human body - a thing, not us. Even if there is enough brain function to keep the heart, lungs, or other organs going then that is not relevant to me (though it does seem to be relevant to the legal definition of death) since that is just the body as a machine / a thing - not the body with the brain function that defines a mental existence / a person or individual. 
 
 If a loved one lost all cerebral brain function then, assuming that I could think rationally over the grief, I would have no choice but to choose to disconnect them from life support since I would have to accept that the person I knew was long gone and that I would only be agreeing to the death of a mere body - a thing, no matter how much that body reminded me of the person who once existed in it. 
 
 All of this translates to the issue of the beginning of life of an individual since I don't view an individual as beginning life until he/she gains the mental existence that defines them. Their life as individuals then starts through newly developed mental capabilities that, according to neurologists, can exist only if a functioning cerebral cortex exists - which starts around the beginning of the third trimester of fetal development.
